titlestmt.titleproper: Zonta Club of Albany; Records apap399
titlestmt.author: Jodi Boyle

publicationstmt.publisher: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-06-29 23:00:17 -0400.

repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: This collection documents the day-to-day activities of the Zonta Club of Albany, a service organization in the Captial Region of New York, comprised of executives, professionals, and businesswomen.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The collection includes newsletters created by the local club, magazines published by Zonta International, local membership directories, meeting minutes, scrapbooks and photo albums, conference and event materials, and ephembera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collections
arrangement.p: The collection is unprocessed and an inventory does not yet exist. Individual items may be difficult to find.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Club archivist Rita Cousino donated all materials in this collection to the M.E. Grenandner Department of Special Collections and Archives in 2022.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted because it is unprocessed. Portions of the collection may contain recent administrative records and/or personally identifiable information. Please contact an archivist for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This page may contain links to digital objects. Access to these images and the technical capacity to download them does not imply permission for re-use. Digital objects may be used freely for personal reference use, referred to, or linked to from other web sites.
Researchers do not have permission to publish or disseminate material from these collections without permission from an archivist and/or the copyright holder.

The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming to the laws of copyright. Some materials in these collections may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) and/or by the copyright or neighboring-rights laws of other nations. More information about U.S. Copyright is provided by the Copyright Office. Additionally, re-use may be restricted by terms of University Libraries gift or purchase agreements, donor restrictions, privacy and publicity rights, licensing and trademarks.
The Department of Special Collections and Archives is eager to hear from any copyright owners who are not properly identified so that appropriate information may be provided in the future.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Zonta Club of Albany Records, 1939-2020. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Zonta Club of Albany Records).

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Formally established in 1929 with 15 women as charter members, the Zonta Club of Albany has been a service organization for nearly a century in New York's Capital District. The first president of the Club was Christine Birrell Kimball, a public relations consultant. The Zonta Club of Albany is part of Zonta International, founded in 1919 in Buffalo, New York, which today has clubs in more than 60 countries worldwide.

Throughout its history, the Zonta Club of Albany has engaged in outreach, conducted fundraising, volunteered, and implemented projects to benefit Capital District women and girls. These efforts have included the building of an interfaith chapel at Memorial Hospital in Albany, contributing toward the formation of Albany Girls Club, and supporting such local programs and organizations as Mercy House, The Next Step, Inc., Albany Medical Center, Albany County Jail Women's Project, the Capital City Rescue Mission's Women and Children's Center, the Equinox Domestic Violence Shelter, and many more.
The Zonta Club of Albany also was instrumental in the establishment of other local Zonta clubs including ones in the Troy area, Montgomery/Fulton, Columbia/Greene area, and Kingston.
